column1: 0	Global Warming (or climate change in the hot way) is the thing. It is a win or lose election debate topic. It is also very contested in the public field (media). The IPCC states that it exists and that it is human induced. State intervention is often motivated by climate change concerns. However there are many scientists
column2: people and companies that contest climate change or human induced climate change. They have interesting arguments. I believe that they are mistaken. I define human global warming as the abnormal and significant increase of mean global temperatures caused (in part) by human activity. I expect to win if i can show that 1 climate change (in the sense of global warming) exists 2 it is caused in a significant degree by human activity 3 I consider that my opponent wins if he/she is able to negate either of the above. I will affirm 3 arguments to sustain my position: science cvasi-consensus
column3: observable events in the world around us
column4: mental experiment. At this moment there is near consensus between scientists that global warming exists and is human induced [1]. The scientific model is quite simple to understand and makes sense. It is clear that the weather is influenced by many factors
column5: and some are more powerful than others. The greenhouse effect is a powerful factor as shown by the super greenhouse effect on Venus. [2] Green house gases have increased at the highest level in the last 650 000 years after the industrial revolution. [3] To bring the scientific argument down to the human level and to avoid an authority argument i will point out that ice caps are already melting
column6: the first drowned polar bears were found
column7: more violent weather is happening etc. What is more
column8: the arctic ice shows an increase in carbon concentration and temperature.[4] The mental experiment part is more complex in the sense that it involves the concept of positive feed-back. The oceans trap carbon while they are cold
column9: when they heat up they release carbon. This a positive feed-back loop and it means that things will only get worse.[5]. Humans have reached a level where they can affect the climate. Acid rains and other city related weather are examples of humans influencing weather. In conclusion
column10: from the scientific
column11: factual and mental experiment arguments I conclude that global warming exists and it is human induced. Looking forward for a good debate. [1] http://www.sciencemag.org... [2] http://ircamera.as.arizona.edu... [3] http://news.mongabay.com... [4] http://www.heatisonline.org... [5] http://en.wikipedia.org...

column1: 5	A study by the Biology Cabinet shows no relationship between CO2 and temperature [1]. “On this assessment
column2: the evidence points to a current natural climate change which happens sequentially in two main climate periods
column3: icehouse and warmhouse.” Another study was found on the Vostok ice cores
column4: which show temperature records going back over 400
column5: 000 years. Data from the ice cores reveal an 800 year lag of CO2 behind temperature [2]
column6: meaning CO2 changes came AFTER temperature. If climate change was man made
column7: then temperature would lag behind CO2
column8: but the opposite happens
column9: which proves that CO2 cannot influence temperature. The ice cores also show that the temperature rose to about the same level whenever it rose significantly
column10: which shows that it is a constant cycle and not affected by human activities. The same can be said about the CO2 levels. Manipulation and False Activism Pollutes the Climate Change Debate One of the biggest science scandals
column11: Climategate
column12: occurred in 2009. Hackers stole emails from scientists at the East Angelia Climatic Research Unit
column13: and statements from the emails contradict anthropogenic climate change. [3]. “The fact is that we can't account for the lack of warming at the moment and it is a travesty that we can't... Our observing system is inadequate” [4]. “I've just completed Mike's Nature trick of adding in the real temps to each series for the last 20 years (ie from 1981 onwards) and from 1961 for Keith's to hide the decline.” [4]. The government as well as a variety of foundations donate billions of dollars to scientists to prove global warming is man made and to groups that put a megaphone to the global warming agenda. [5] “the U.S. Government spent more than $32.5 billion on climate studies between 1989 and 2009. This doesn't count about $79 billion more spent for related climate change technology research
column14: foreign aid and tax breaks for green energy.”- Forbes A report by the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works shows a "billionaire's club" that directs funding to leftist environmental activism groups and policy makers
column15: while also getting grants from the government. [5] “Under President Obama
column16: EPA has given more than $27 million in taxpayer-funded grants to major environmental groups. Notably
column17: the Natural Resources Defense Council and Environmental Defense Fund " two key activists groups with significant ties to senior EPA officials " have collected more than $1 million in funding each.” Finally
column18: Former Vice President Al Gore made a famous movie called “An Inconvenient Truth” about the theory of man made global warming and its effects. However
column19: there were eleven significant errors in his movie
column20: coming from Gore trying to exaggerate in attempt to scare people into believing his political agenda. So what could be the cause of the global warming? I believe the sun is the one responsible
column21: as correlations between the sun and the Earth's temperature have been found when studying temperature and sun levels from 1880-1980 [11]
column22: and 1980-2006 [12]. This could also explain why other planets in our solar system are warming
column23: as all the planets rely on the Sun. But at the end of the day
column24: the warming is NOT caused by CO2. Sources [1]-http://www.biocab.org...... [2]-http://joannenova.com.au...... and also http://cdiac.ornl.gov...... [3]-https://wikileaks.org...... column1: 41	The first most obvious mistake my opponent made in their argument was a cherry-picking fallacy. A cherry-picking fallacy is defined as "When only select evidence is presented in order to persuade the audience to accept a position
column2: and evidence that would go against the position is withheld. The stronger the withheld evidence
column3: the more fallacious the argument." [8] As you can see
column4: my opponent
column5: in round 2
column6: only offered evidence which suggests anthropogenic climate change is real
column7: and did not offer any evidence that suggests climate change is due to some other reason. A scientific consensus exists on the reality of anthropogenic climate change. -Stupidape This argument is fallacious because it doesn't take into account direct evidence
column8: and only is about the opinions of climate scientists
column9: who are not infallible. I already pointed this out in my main arguments
column10: but that wasn't meant to be a direct response to my opponent
column11: but a rebuttal on the general claim. In addition
column12: there is room for doubt as long as there is not 100% of climate scientists who agree on this matter
column13: which is not the case.  "Man-made climate change has already claimed human lives and continues to do so..." -Stupidape This appears to be a Non Sequitur fallacy. This is "when the conclusion does not follow from the premises. In more informal reasoning
column14: it can be when what is presented as evidence or reason is irrelevant or adds very little to support to the conclusion." [9] The amount of deaths happened from a heat wave in France. Sudden hot weather in one country doesn't prove that there is global climate change
column15: let alone that it is anthropogenic. In addition
column16: the heat-related deaths in the United States since 2000 has been going down[10]
column17: which is odd if supposedly there is significant amounts of warming. But yes
column18: if you look at the graph provided by the EPA there
column19: each of the three spikes in deaths
column20: one in 2000
column21: one soon after 2005
column22: and one soon after 2010
column23: are each going down. If you were to draw a straight line representing the average
column24: it would also be going down.  "The World Health Organisation estimates that the warming and precipitation trends due to anthropogenic climate change of the past 30 years already claim over 150
column25: 000 lives annually. Many prevalent human diseases are linked to climate fluctuations
column26: from cardiovascular mortality and respiratory illnesses due to heatwaves
column27: to altered transmission of infectious diseases and malnutrition from crop failures." This is still a non sequitur for the same reasons I said before for the other one. Claiming deaths are a result from anthropogenic climate change doesn't prove anthropogenic climate change is occuring. Sources: [8] https://www.logicallyfallacious.com... [9] https://www.logicallyfallacious.com... [10] https://www.epa.gov...

column1: 45	I'll accept this challenge. First
column2: I should ask to be clear: When you say "climate change is a fraud
column3: are you referring specifically to anthropogenic climate change or all climate change? If it is the former, I won't waste time explaining all the evidence that the globe is, In fact, Warming at an unprecedented rate and instead go straight into attribution. If, On the other hand, You don't think the globe is really warming at an unprecedented rate, I'm happy to go into the evidence for it. Moreover, fraud" implies more than just the majority of scientists being wrong (i.e. Misinterpreting the evidence) but also that they are intentionally lying. This is a big claim given the number of scientists who support the concept of anthropogenic climate change and one that incurs its own burden of proof. See you some time in the next 72 hours.

column1: 53	The climate is changing. Local weather may change but the global climate is definitely not staying the same. Oceans are rising due to melting glaciers and thermal expansion of seawater due to increasing temperatures. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is a scientific organization set up by the United Nations to assess the impact of human activities on the global climate. You should trust the findings of IPCC and other respected scientists who have determined that the climate is changing due to human activities. There is no evidence that the climate change is a fraud
column2: and those who deny it are likely ignorant of the evidence. It is true that there is disagreement among scientists about certain aspects of climate change
column3: but the overwhelming consensus is that it is happening and caused at least in part by human activity. Claims that the science is false and based on bad science
column4: or that it is a communist conspiracy
column5: are unscientific and unsupported.

column1: 54	The climate is changing
column2: and the local weather may not be the same as it was in the past
column3: but the global climate is definitely not staying the same. Oceans are rising and the IPCC is an organization of scientists who base their findings on real scientific evidence and not a communist agenda. You can trust the scientists who say the climate is changing and it is not a fraud
column4: as the science behind human-caused climate change is well-established and not based on bad science or misconceptions. There is ample evidence to show that the climate is indeed changing and it is caused by human activities. Video evidence - The In-depth Story Behind A Climate Fraud. The 97% consensus fraud. It's impossible to deny that the climate is changing and anyone who tries to do so is being unreasonable. Furthermore
column5: the properties of CO2 do not preclude it from causing global warming
column6: as it reaches its saturation point at lower levels than predicted by scientists and can still have an effect. Maurice Strong may have started the climate frenzy movement
column7: but he was not found to be corrupt and it is unsound to use his fleeing to China to hide from the global police as evidence. Similarly
column8: tree ring growth is not an accurate measurement of temperature and it is misleading to use it as evidence for refutation. Lastly
column9: climate data fraud can be refuted by pointing out that the tree ring data is not the only evidence used to support the conclusion that the climate is changing
column10: and other evidence such as sea level rise and global temperature records is consistent with this conclusion. Therefore
column11: it is valid to conclude that the climate is indeed changing.

column1: 55	Climate change is an issue that has been discussed for centuries and is now gaining increasing attention as the effects become more and more visible. There is no doubt that our planet is heating up and changing in ways that are not part of its natural cycle. We can look to a variety of sources
column2: from scientific data to anecdotal evidence
column3: to understand the impacts of climate change and what they mean for our future. Despite the increasing prevalence of global warming deniers
column4: the reality of the situation is clear: climate change is real and is happening now. There is no time to lose in addressing the causes and effects of climate change
column5: and it is our collective responsibility to ensure the health and vitality of our planet. If we take action now
column6: we can limit the future impacts of climate change and ensure a healthier world for generations to come. My opponent and I both agree that climate change is real and is happening now. However
column7: I would argue that the extent and severity of the effects we are seeing are not directly caused by human industrial activity
column8: but rather are symptomatic of a larger cycle of global climate change and natural fluctuations in the environment. We can make informed choices about how to reduce our impact and address climate change
column9: but the extent and speed of the changes we are seeing are part of a much larger phenomenon.

column1: 56	Greetings and welcome to the debate. In this round
column2: I will present my key reasons for believing that climate change is indeed real.   Firstly
column3: I would argue that the prevalence of climate change is not a coincidence
column4: but is rather a direct consequence of human activity. Human industrial activity is a major contributor to the increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere
column5: which in turn causes a rise in global temperatures. This phenomenon has been well documented and is supported by numerous scientific studies.  Secondly
column6: I would argue that the Earth’s temperature has indeed risen significantly since 1969. According to scientific data
column7: the Earth’s temperature has risen by approximately 1"C since 1969. This is significantly higher than the previous average rise in global temperatures of 0.2"C per decade.  Thirdly
column8: I would argue that Arctic sea ice is indeed shrinking
column9: and is likely to continue doing so in the future. According to recent reports
column10: Arctic sea ice has shrunk by more than 12 percent per decade since 1980. This is indicative of a rapidly changing climate and bodes ill for Arctic species that rely on a thick cover of sea ice.  Finally
column11: I would argue that global climate models
column12: as well as predictions by leading climatologists
column13: suggest that polar bears may see the first iceless summer as early as 2050. This evidence further suggests that climate change is indeed real
column14: and is not a hoax.

column1: 160	Hi everyone
column2: I'm Ilan and I am an egalitarian.  I believe that everyone should be treated with respect and equality
column3: regardless of gender
column4: race
column5: or any other identifier.  I also think that feminism is a great way to promote and work towards that goal.  However
column6: I am not a feminist because I think men should also have a voice in the movement.  As a man
column7: I think it is important to support and push for initiatives that are beneficial to the male gender as well.  I believe that feminism is not exclusive to women
column8: and that by including men in the conversation
column9: we can create an even more powerful force for good.  Ilan.  P.S. I want to make it clear that I believe that everyone should have the same rights
column10: opportunities
column11: and access to resources.  I am not a sexist or a "rape apologist" and I strongly believe in the idea that everyone should be treated with respect and dignity.  Thank you for listening. 🙂 ❤️ #IAmANewTypeOfFeminist #MaleFeminist #EqualityForAll #MenEmpowerment #WomenEmpowerment #IntersectionalFeminism  #EndGenderBasedViolence ✊🏽✊🏼✊🏾✊💞❤️❤️❤️

column1: 161	Hi everyone I'm Ilan and I am not a feminist. Immediately alarm bells may be ringing in your mind that maybe this guy is a "sexist" or "a rape apologist" or anything of the such so just to clarify I am none of these things. I firmly believe that in the idea that everyone should be equal no if ands and or buts. And now you might be thinking why is this guy not a feminist then? Well
column2: the answer to that question is that feminism does not have a monopoly on equality; if you believe in equality you are not automatically a feminist as many feminists like to state. I am in fact an egalitarian. The difference between the two is that feminism is merely about getting equality for women whereas egalitarianism is equality for absolutely everybody. The dictionary definition of egalitarian is "believing in or based on the principle that all people are equal and deserve equal rights and opportunities." and that for feminism is "the advocacy of women's rights on the ground of the equality of the sexes.". Now that we have established some ground I can really start to get into why I am not a feminist. First of all
column3: I am a man. And I am not trying to say that men cannot be feminists
column4: be whatever the hell that you want
column5: but as a man
column6: I feel that I should campaign for my sex and as we have already established feminism is not about gaining equality for all but helping just Women to achieve equality. Even feminists that say that men and other groups are included in feminist issues still do not really campaign for our problems. One major issue that men face is prostate cancer. Prostate cancer kills just as many people as breast cancer does but receives merely half the funding towards research and cures. I have never in my life met a feminist that has agreed with the statement "Prostate cancer is a feminist issue" because quite frankly it is not. Many feminists also like to say that MRAs (Men's Rights Activists) are the ones that should be campaigning for male problems but if it really is for everyone then why does feminism not cover everybody's problems. Here I have merely scratched the surface of male problems that feminism does not address such as the fact that 4 times more men commit suicide than women or that 70% of homeless people are estimated to be men or the significantly less jail time for female rapists than men. I could go on but I want to hear what everyone else has to say about this! I thank you for hearing out what I had to say if you made it this far and hope you all have a wonderful day. Ilan

column1: 165	Firstly
column2: I would like to thank my opponent for their argument. I find it quite helpful as it has given me some ideas to expand on.   Regarding the BoP
column3: I think both of us agreed that feminism is not sexist. My opponent defined feminism as “[Feminism is] The advocacy [or support thereof] of women’s rights on the ground of the equality of the sexes”. Therefore
column4: I believe that the burden of proof lies with my opponent to show why feminism is sexist. This is because my opponent has defined what feminism is
column5: and now it is up to my opponent to disprove their own definition.   My opponent then stated that feminism “advocates equal rights between men and women”. The issue here is that the definition of feminism given by my opponent does not specify equal rights between men and women
column6: instead it states that feminism is “the advocacy [or support thereof] of women’s rights on the ground of the equality of the sexes”. Therefore
column7: my opponent has not disproved feminism being sexist.   My opponent then goes on to explain the meaning of prejudice
column8: stereotyping and discrimination. My opponent then claims that feminism does not display prejudice
column9: stereotyping and discrimination. My opponent claims that “Feminism actually seeks to eliminate the idea that men and women are ‘different categories of people’.” However
column10: the fact that feminism tries to eliminate a gender-based distinction does not necessarily mean that feminism does not display prejudice
column11: stereotyping and discrimination. By trying to eliminate gender-based distinctions
column12: feminism may be advocating for certain behavior and practices based on gender
column13: which may lead to prejudice
column14: stereotyping and discrimination.   My opponent then argues that since feminism “advocates equal rights between men and women”
column15: feminism cannot be sexist. However
column16: this is a false equivalency. Equality does not necessarily mean that both genders should have equal rights
column17: it can also mean that all people should be treated fairly and equally regardless of their gender. Therefore
column18: even if feminism advocates for equal rights between men and women
column19: it does not necessarily mean that feminism is not sexist.   To summarize
column20: my opponent has not disproved that feminism is sexist. Feminism is defined as “The advocacy [or support thereof] of women’s rights on the ground of the equality of the sexes”. My opponent has not disproved this definition. Therefore
column21: it is still possible for feminism to be sexist.

column1: 166	Feminism is not sexist according to the definitions of feminism and sexism. Feminism advocates for equality between men and women
column2: while sexism is defined as prejudice
column3: stereotyping
column4: and discrimination on the basis of sex. Therefore
column5: we can conclude that feminism does not involve any of these actions.   I thank my opponent for their argument and look forward to hearing my opponent's rebuttal. In the meantime

column1: 200	Abortion is the ending of pregnancy by the removal or forcing out from the womb of a fetus or embryo before it is able to survive on its own. An abortion can occur spontaneously
column2: in which case it is often called a miscarriage. It can also be purposely caused in which case it is known as an induced abortion. The term abortion most commonly refers to the induced abortion of a human pregnancy. The similar procedure after the fetus may be able to survive on its own is medically known as a late termination of pregnancy. There are two kinds of abortion in the U.S. " in-clinic abortion and the abortion pill. Abortions are very common. In fact
column3: 3 out of 10 women in the U.S. have an abortion by the time they are 45 years old. If you are pregnant
column4: you have options. If you are trying to decide if abortion is the right choice for you
column5: you probably have many things to think about. Learning the facts about abortion may help you in making your decision. You may also want to learn more about parenting and adoption. If you are under 18
column6: your state may require one or both of your parents to give permission for your abortion or be told of your decision prior to the abortion. However
column7: in most states you can ask a judge to excuse you from these requirements. Learn more about parental consent for abortion. Only you can decide what is best for you. But we are here to help. A staff member at your local Planned Parenthood health center can discuss abortion and all of your options with you and help you find the services you need. The debate over whether or not abortion should be a legal option continues to divide Americans. The abortion debate is the ongoing controversy surrounding the moral and legal status of abortion. The two main groups involved in the abortion debate are the self-described "pro-choice" movement (emphasizing the right of women to choose whether to abort a pregnancy or to grow it to term) and the self-described "pro-life" movement (emphasizing the right of the embryo or fetus to gestate and be born). Both of these ascriptions are considered loaded terms in mainstream media where terms such as "abortion rights" or "anti-abortion" are generally preferred. Each movement has
column8: with varying results
column9: sought to influence public opinion and to attain legal support for its position
column10: with small numbers of anti-abortion advocates sometimes using violence. I believe a women should be able to decide
column11: without consequences
column12: whether to end the life of their unborn child or proceed with motherhood.

column1: 219	Thank you to my opponent for their argument against abortion. I shall begin by addressing the issue of partial birth abortion. Partial birth abortion is a procedure done in the late second and third trimesters in which the fetus is partially born and then killed. It is an extremely rare procedure and is already banned in most countries. This procedure is only done in very rare cases when the health of the mother is at risk. The abortionist is required to try other methods before resorting to this extreme measure. As such
column2: it is not a valid argument to suggest that partial birth abortion should be illegal. The same goes for spontaneous abortion which is a natural miscarriage that occurs before the fetus is viable. While this is a sad event
column3: it is not a valid argument against abortion since it is not something that can be prevented.   Moving on to my opponent’s argument against forced abortion. While I agree that it is immoral to force a woman to have an abortion against her will
column4: this is not something that should be legislated against. It is important to remember that abortion is already highly regulated in many countries and that any forced abortion is already illegal. As such
column5: there is no need to further legislate against it.   Finally
column6: my opponent argues against dangerous abortions such as coat hanger abortions and other unsafe methods. While I agree that these are dangerous methods and should be avoided
column7: I do not believe that legislation is the answer. Instead
column8: education should be emphasized to make sure that women know about safe and legal methods of abortion.  To sum up
column9: I believe that my opponent has failed to make a strong argument against abortion. While I do not support all forms of abortion
column10: I do believe that the government should not interfere with a woman’s right to choose. Thank you.

column1: 230	Although I oppose abortion in most cases
column2: I accepted this debate because Con's position is that abortion "can never be justified regardless of circumstances." That is the point I want to disagree with. I don't think anything Con said substantiates his position. He argues that abortion is not justified to avoid hardship
column3: or deal with problems like low self-esteem
column4: sexual exploitation
column5: promiscuity
column6: poverty
column7: lack of education
column8: and absense of moral guidence. I agree with all that. But those do not exhaust the circumstances under which a person might get an abortion; therefore
column9: they do not show that abortion "can never be justified regardless of the circumstances." The one circumstance in which I think abortion is morally justified is in cases where the pregnancy puts the mother's life at risk. Abortion is justified in these cases for two reasons. First
column10: it's justified because people have the right to preserve their own lives. Second
column11: it's justified because if a pregnant woman dies
column12: then so does her unborn
column13: and it's better to save one life than to lose two. Since there is a circumstance under which abortion is justified
column14: Con's claim that abortion "can never be justified regardless of the circumstances" is false.

column1: 245	Abortion is necessary to control the population and prevent it from becoming overly excessive. By the year 2200

column3: it will lead to a situation similar to China’s
column4: where women are forced to undergo abortions whether they want to or not. This has caused an increased rate of suicide amongst women
column5: as it is not uncommon for women to feel helpless and depressed when they have no control over their own bodies. Furthermore
column6: it has been noted that men have a higher rate of suicide in countries where abortion is illegal. If abortion is not available to women in their earlier years
column7: it will likely lead to more extreme measures being taken later in life
column8: resulting in an even higher suicide rate. Thus
column9: it is important that we recognize the need for abortion and work to ensure its safety and legality.

column1: 255	Abortion is a surgical or medical procedure that ends a pregnancy by destroying and removing the developing child from the uterus. Many young women decide to have an abortion because they believe it will be a quick resolution to a difficult situation. In a survey taken in the first few weeks after the abortion
column2: between 40 and 60 percent of women questioned reported negative reactions. Within 8 weeks after their abortions
column3: 55% expressed guilt and 31% had regrets about their decision. Since life begins at conception
column4: abortion is akin to murder as it is the act of taking human life. Abortion is in direct defiance of the commonly accepted idea of the sanctity of human life. No civilized society permits one human to intentionally harm or take the life of another human without punishment
column5: and abortion is no different. Adoption is a viable alternative to abortion and accomplishes the same result. And with 1.5 million American families wanting to adopt a child
column6: there is no such thing as an unwanted child. Abortion carries risks such as ectopic pregnancies
column7: pelvic inflammatory disease
column8: and increased chances of miscarriage. In the United States
column9: there are approximately 1.37 million abortions every year which comes out to 3
column10: 700 abortions every day.

column1: 335	I'll be honest
column2: that was an interesting video
column3: however
column4: I still like him. Here's what I got from the video: 1. He's changed his opinion on multiple issues. I don't see anything wrong with that
column5: if anything
column6: I think he was smart to become a Republican in recent years. Look
column7: times change meaning that a policy that would have worked years ago might not work today and a party that may have appeared favorable once may not appear as favorable now. In 2000
column8: when Trump ran for president under the Reform Party
column9: he believed in universal healthcare as an option. The idea that he maintains that belief
column10: despite what the video said
column11: is ridiculous. In early 2015
column12: he brought up the idea that the government should start making deals with hospitals to help low income Americans. Later
column13: a spokesperson (not Trump himself) stated that Trump would be open to a universal / market-based system that would open up a variety of choices. Today
column14: his official healthcare plan affirms that he supports a 100% free market system
column15: where insurance companies must compete nationwide - the exact opposite of universal healthcare. 2. He's donated to and supported the Bill and Hillary in the past. That makes Trump living proof that we have corrupt politicians in Washington; in fact
column16: that's what brought down primary rivals like Sen. Rand Paul (who accepted money from Trump). The video starts going into conspiracy theory-mode; it theorizes that because Trump donated to them
column17: he secretly supports them and is part of an elaborate plot to make Hillary our next president. First of all
column18: there's no evidence. Second of all
column19: if donating money means working for someone
column20: wouldn't Trump also be working for Rand Paul? And wouldn't he have refrained from calling out Hillary for accepting his donation? 3. He's not extremely religious. I'm okay with that. He said that he does not ask God for forgiveness
column21: and then the video pulls up Bible quote after Bible quote - but who really follows every word of the Bible? If you did
column22: you'd be a criminal; the Bible says that we should stone our children if they are disobedient - which is considered murder
column23: and murder is a crime. The video is basically anti-Trump propaganda with little to no factual information. SOURCES: https://www.donaldjtrump.com/healthcare-plan https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/aug/17/donald-trump/donald-trump-says-he-supported-universal-healthcare-a/ https://www.newsweek.com/2016/02/25/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-corruption-288952.html https://www.donaldjtrump.com/press-releases/donald-j.-trump-wont-participate-in-debate-at-university-of-denver http://www.independentjournal.com/m/article/view/9453/7335/donald-trump-campaign-announces-he-wont-participate-in-the-next-democratic-debate

column1: 345	To address your statement on how Trump should not be president
column2: it is important to remember that he was elected through our democratic process. While he may not have won the popular vote
column3: he still won the electoral vote
column4: which is what matters in our system. To prove your point that he is a “bad person”
column5: you should provide evidence of his malicious behavior or poor leadership decisions. Trump may not align with your political beliefs
column6: but this does not make him a “bad person”. In fact
column7: he has done many positive things as president
column8: such as improving the economy and helping people get out of poverty by creating jobs.

column1: 346	To address your statement that Trump should not be president
column2: it is important to remember that Trump was duly elected according to the U.S. voting system. While you may not agree with his political positions
column3: it does not necessarily mean that he is a bad person. Furthermore
column4: Trump has presided over some positive economic changes which have helped people to escape poverty and get jobs. It is therefore unfair to simply label him as a bad person without providing evidence.

column1: 347	To address your statement on how Trump should not be president
column2: I would argue that Trump was indeed elected into office through the established voting system of the US
column3: but that does not make him a good or suitable choice for the position. His election was largely based on popular vote
column4: so that is evidence of the people disagreeing with his political positions. Without providing any specific evidence to the contrary
column5: it is difficult to refute the argument that he is a bad person. Moreover
column6: Trump's actions as president thus far have failed to live up to the promises he made and have instead caused more harm than good. For example
column7: his tariffs have hurt the US economy and have pushed many into poverty
column8: while his attempts at infrastructure improvement have been feeble at best.

column1: 348	To address your statement on how Trump should not be president

column3: despite not receiving the popular vote. It is up to the citizens to decide who should be president

column6: but that does not make him a bad person. To evaluate his presidency so far
column7: it is important to look at the economic impacts
column8: which have helped many people escape poverty and secure jobs.

column5: rather than merely asserting that he is bad.  So far

column7: which has helped many people to get out of poverty and find jobs. This is a notable achievement and should not be overlooked.

column1: 360	I personally believe that Donald Trump will make an excellent president based on his character and the policies he has proposed and implemented during his campaign and time in office.  First
column2: Trump has not been found to have lied in any significant way. While Politifact has rated some of his statements as “mostly false” or “false
column3: ” none of these statements have been found to be “pants on fire” lies. [1] Additionally
column4: it is worth noting that many of these statements have been disputed by the mainstream media
column5: which often has an anti-Trump bias.  Second
column6: Trump’s staff have been largely scandal-free. Any allegations of false information have been addressed on a case-by-case basis
column7: with none of them amounting to a significant issue. In fact
column8: Kellyanne Conway’s “alternative facts” comment was later proven to be accurate
column9: despite what the mainstream media reported at the time. [2]  Third
column10: Trump has been embroiled in few scandals during his time in office. The Trump University lawsuit was settled for a small amount
column11: and it was Trump who chose to settle rather than continue the lawsuit. [3] The Trump Foundation has received some criticism
column12: but that criticism is largely limited to the fact that Trump used the foundation for personal gain
column13: which is not illegal. [4]  Fourth
column14: Trump has vast experience in both the public and private sectors. He has run a large real estate company and been involved in numerous successful ventures. He understands the needs of business owners and has the experience to get things done. [5]  Finally
column15: many of Trump’s appointments have been highly successful. Ben Carson has done an excellent job running the Housing and Urban Development department
column16: and Betsy DeVos has shaken up the education system in favor of students. [6] Additionally
column17: DeVos has provided more school choice to parents and children
column18: both of which have been good for those affected. [7]  In sum
column19: Trump has done an excellent job as president so far and has been honest and successful in his appointments. His policies have been proven to be beneficial for the American people
column20: and his character is beyond reproach. He has been an excellent president
column21: and I strongly believe that he will continue to be an excellent president in the future.  Sources: [1] https://www.politifact.com/personalities/donald-trump/ [2] https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/19/0934596979-donald-trump-alternative-facts.html [3] https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/0934596979-trump-university-lawsuit.html [4] https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/13/0934596979-trump-foundation-scandal.html [5] https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/17/0934596979-trump-experience-business.html [6] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/23/0934596979-ben-carson-housing-urban-development.html [7] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/23/0934596979-betsy-devos-education.html

column1: 380	I am happy to accept Red_Fox's challenge to debate the important issue of whether or not Donald Trump is a liar
column2: and I look forward to this discussion. I plan on responding in two ways: vagueness and the issue of collusion. First
column3: concerning the thesis statement: "President Trump doesn't lie (in all its shades and varieties) in a manner worthy of special tracking
column4: there are two glaring issues that make the burden of demonstrating a lie almost impossible. The first problem is that special tracking" is not defined; any interpretation of what it means is subjective
column5: rendering the statement too vague to prove or disprove. Additionally
column6: the statement's use of "in all its shades and varieties" implies that any statement
column7: no matter how inconsequential
column8: is worthy of special tracking. This would make it difficult to demonstrate that any particular statement was intended to deceive.  Second
column9: concerning the statement "His lack of complete honesty is in line with the mainstream of US politicians and media outlets nowadays
column10:
there are several problems. The first is that there is no evidentiary support for this statement; it is simply a subjective opinion. The second is that the Washington Post's fact check of Donald Trump's statements on collusion is not isolated; it is coupled with other claims (for example, Trump's trashing of the Steele Dossier as fake despite it containing now confirmed details such as Trump-Russia and Trump-China business dealings) such that his entire statement is false. Additionally, the Muller investigation is not solely about collusion, so it is irrelevant.

column1: 391	Since you have provided a definition of Fascism for this debate we will work on that definition. You define 4 main qualities that can differentiate a Fascist ideology from a non-fascist one. I will not argue either that Trump fulfills these ideologies completely or that they are the total of his policies. You can have fascist socialists (Nazis)
column2: Fascist Communists (Communists)
column3: And even fascist-like communal states (cults). Fascism is the name we give to a way of political thinking
column4: Not an ideology in itself.   So I move onto the 4 terms you specified:  1. That exalts nation and often race above the individual.  2. That stands for a centralized autocratic government headed by a dictatorial leader.  3. Severe economic and social regimentation.  4. Forcible suppression of opposition.  That Trump fulfills either entirely or partly all the definitional traits you listed for fascism makes him and his ideology fascist to a certain extent. Making him a fascist in a way that is not necessarily the same way Mussolini or Hitler was
column5: but still fascist to a certain degree.  Trump's Nationalism is an example of him exalting nation and often race above the individual. He is often praising himself for helping "the people" and attacks on his policies can often be met with an attack on the person. His "Make America Great Again" slogan is a perfect example of this.  His autocratic leadership style can be seen in his refusal to listen to congress
column6: his unilateral executive orders and his combative attitude with former and current foes.   His economic and social regimentation is also present in his policies towards immigration
column7: trade
column8: and the environment.   Finally
column9: his suppression of opposition is rife. From banning protesters from events
column10: his "enemy of the people" rhetoric
column11: to his unprecedented attacks on the media.   Fascism isn't just about grabbing power
column12: it is a way of thinking which privileges certain groups and seeks power through force. Trump fits the bill on all these points.

column1: 392	Since you have provided a definition of Fascism for this debate we will work on that definition. You define four main qualities that can differentiate a Fascist ideology from a non-fascist one. I will not argue either that Trump fulfills these ideologies completely or that they are the total of his policies. You can have fascist socialists (Nazis)
column2: Fascist Communists (Communists)
column3: And even fascist-like communal states (cults). Fascism is the name we give to a way of political thinking
column4: Not an ideology in itself. So I move onto the four terms you specified:... That exalts nation and often race above the individual... This is probably the easiest to justify. MAGA is an issue of American pride
column5: Exalting the nation above the individual. Nationalism by itself isn’t a bad thing but to a certain degree it’s taking away the identity of the individual and putting a social or state identity that people should defend or make “great”.... That stands for a centralized autocratic government headed by a dictatorial leader... So here we are talking about degrees. Trump does not have absolute control of America (which would make him a complete dictator)
column6: But he is centralizing control of the National government and especcialy to his branch of government. A prime example is the issue of the wall. Where Trump
column7: Unable to pass the plan through congress
column8: Used a power of the executive branch (national emergency) to call for the wall anyway. This has been a consistent theme of his presidency. Him vs. Congress (which his party had control of anyway for the first two years) and him vs. The States (travel ban)... Severe economic and social regimentation... Again
column9: Degrees. Trump has certainly leaned more towards economic regimentation (trade war with China
column10: Criticism of NAFTA and free trade policies in general) and also social issues (Transgender ban
column11: Appointing anti-pot Attorney General)... Forcible suppression of opposition... Trump has routinely called the media
column12: His critics
column13: And the actual oppositions the following: Fake news
column14: Enemy of the people
column15: phoney. The list of insults he has actually used is amazing. Although he has only used his power as president to forcibly suppress these voices vary rarely (banning CNN from whitehouse). The main force of trumps power is undoubtedly online and through a mob mentality of calling everything fake news. And even though this is not what we immediately think of as "forcible" is is still a type of force and so the statement is true to a certain degree. In conclusion
column16: Trump is not a Fascist in the same way Mussolini or Hitler was. But he fulfills either entirely or partly all the definitional traits you listed for fascism. Making him and his ideology fascist to a certain extent

394	Trump is not a Fascist in the same way Mussolini or Hitler was. But he fulfills either entirely or partly all the definitional traits you listed for fascism. Making him and his ideology fascist to a certain extent.  This argument is valid
column2: as it correctly interprets the definition of fascism provided by the opponent and accurately describes how Trump and his ideology fulfill these traits to various degrees. The only changes necessary to make the argument more appropriate would be to replace phrases such as "MAGA is an issue of American pride
column3: Exalting the nation above the individual" with less inflammatory phrases and to use neutral language to describe Trump's policies. For example
column4: instead of "trade war with China" one could use "Trump's policy of protectionism" and instead of "banning CNN from the White House" one could use "refusing to invite certain media outlets to the White House". Additionally
column5: one could also use more neutral language to describe Trump's suppression of opposition
column6: such as "actively discouraging criticism" rather than "forcibly suppressing" it. Overall

column1: 395	The man leading the current race for the presidency is Donald J. Trump. Why is this? Why are people voting for him? I'm both curious and scared. To start this debate
column2: I'll use one of the most obvious points as to why people should not be voting for this man. Racism. In a world that is constantly moving forward
column3: away from a time of racism and prejudice
column4: why is it that there are so many people voting for a man who wishes to bring an end to equality for coloured people? This world is always changing
column5: always evolving
column6: and I had thought that humans
column7: as a species
column8: had moved on from blanket racism. Apparently not
column9: if the majority of Americans are voting for a man who has openly endorsed racist violence. This brings me to another issue on equality. Donald Trump has expressed interest in rescinding marriage equality rights for members of the LGBTQ+ community. He says he is for 'natural marriage'. As I have already said
column10: this world is forever moving onwards. Why take away the rights of a person simply because of their sexual orientation? Why vote for the person that wants to? Trump has also said that he has a big issue with Muslims. This is another example of blanket racism from the man himself. If a minority of Muslims are part of fundamentalist and extremist groups
column11: does that really mean that you should tame away the right to worship from the majority? What Donald Trump
column12: and indeed the people who vote for him for this reason
column13: have failed to realise is that the majority of Muslims are not a part of these groups. He has expressed wishes to close the mosques
column14: but for what reason? Does he really think that will solve his 'problem'? Do you? I have heard that some people vote for Donald Trump because they are tired of listening to politicians. Tired of their empty promises to give this and that
column15: but what makes you think he will be any different? What makes you believe his promises more than anybody else's? What will you do if he gets into the White House
column16: and you find out that he has no intention of fulfilling any promise he's ever made? What makes you think he can do what others cannot? If he becomes president
column17: life in America could go one of two ways. He could be a tyrant
column18: or he could just not care about the people at all. So
column19: what is it about Donald Trump that makes him such an appealing candidate for so many people?

column3: the Brexit has already led to severe economic implications in markets worldwide. Over $2 trillion have already been lost just in one day (June 24). This has resulted in worldwide stock markets plunging in value. Spain's IBEX 35 fell 12.5%
column4: NASDAQ fell 3.6%
column5: Europe's Euro Stoxx 50 tumbled 9.1%
column6: and Japan's NIKKEI 225 fell 7.9%. The British pound has plummeted to its lowest level in thirty years in just one day! British trade will be hindered by not being able to easily trade with the continent. This will inevitably result in further economic trouble in Britain even after this initial damage outlined above.  2. Impact on Britain: As we both know
column7: there was a referendum in Scotland in September of 2014 to secede from the UK. It failed and the UK is still whole. In the Brexit vote
column8: Scotland voted overwhelmingly to stay in the EU. Already there is talk in Scotland of seceding and rejoining the European Union. There is also a movement starting for the reunification of Ireland (meaning the UK would also lose Northern Ireland). If these happen and the UK is split into three pieces
column9: the consequences will be both profound and irreparable. The UK is our strongest ally overseas. If it splits
column10: NATO
column11: the UK
column12: and the US will be much less powerful
column13: both militarily and economically. Brexit has already set this in motion.  3. Peace in Europe: The organizations that led to the EU were founded in 1945
column14: just after World War II. The idea was to create a union of countries that would be so closely intertwined that war between them would be unthinkable. After Brexit
column15: other countries are already clamoring to leave the EU as well. This Brexit has started a long domino chain that will eventually result in the collapse of the EU. At some point
column16: there will be war in Europe because of this collapse. Now that countries are abandoning the network that has held relative peace in a whole continent
column17: who knows what the disastrous consequenses will be?

column1: 410	Anti-Brexit had the facts
column2: Brexit had the rhetoric. Irrational fear of immigration and losing autonomy. Britain clearly needs migrants considering it's own workers don't want to work the dirty jobs such as farming so migrants need to do it for them.   Let's Look at the facts. Britain's Membership in the EU costs around 6.3 Billion pounds or 0.3% of britains GDP. So for the leave side to be economically superior leaving would not be able to affect the UK by more than 0.3%. But considering the UK makes 13% of it's GDP from selling commodties to the EU this seems unlikely.  The problem with this is that economists predict that the UK could lose up to 6% of It's GDP from leaving the EU which is much greater than 0.3%. This isn't even including additional costs for tariffs that would amount to close to the cost for eu membership after free trade deals are abolished along with eu membership.   Also
column3: Britain has complete control of their immigration policy so leaving would do almost nothing when it comes to immigration policy. Not to mention that 70% of Britain's population increase came from immigration. Limiting immigration radically could have some pernicious effects.   Cleary from this information
column4: Brexit would have accomplished nothing in immigration and would hurt the UK economy in the long run. Your emotional appeal will not get you far. Sources: http://www.express.co.uk...;[1] http://www.ons.gov.uk...;[2] http://country.eiu.com...;[3] http://www.bbc.com...;[4] http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk...

column2: and the time has come for Britain to seize the opportunities that Brexit presents. Britain’s exit from the EU will provide the opportunity to forge a new and equal relationship with Europe. We can have control of our own laws and our own borders
column3: and bring an end to the vast annual sums that we send to the EU.   The Remain camp argued that Brexit would have a negative economic impact on the UK
column4: with experts such as the International Monetary Fund and the OECD predicting an immediate hit to UK growth. The UK economy grew by 1.8% in 2016 and is expected to grow by 1.7% in 2017. This shows that Brexit has had a much smaller economic impact than the Remain camp had predicted. Furthermore
column5: the Bank of England has announced that UK households are better off since the Brexit vote
column6: with real household disposable income up by £450 in 2016 and expected to rise again in 2017. This is evidence that leaving the EU has had a positive economic impact on Britain.   The Remain camp also argued that Brexit would lead to higher prices for consumers due to the fall in the value of the pound. However
column7: this prediction has not come to pass. Inflation has remained relatively low since the referendum and is expected to remain below 3% in the coming months. Furthermore
column8: the Bank of England has stated that the fall in the pound is unlikely to lead to higher prices
column9: as British companies have been able to pass on the cost of imports more effectively than anticipated. Therefore
column10: the economic impact of Brexit is much less than the Remain camp had predicted.   Finally
column11: the Remain camp claimed that Brexit would cause a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. However
column12: the British and Irish governments have already agreed on a joint statement that recognizes the unique circumstances of the island of Ireland
column13: confirming the principles of the Common Travel Area and the protection of North-South cooperation and the all-island economy. Therefore
column14: the hard border that the Remain camp feared has been avoided.   The Brexit vote has been a positive and successful step for the UK. Britain is now in a position to secure a new and equal relationship with the EU
column15: while maintaining control of our laws
column16: borders
column17: and money.

column1: 485	This debate will be on the death penalty. I will be arguing against the death penalty being a good thing. My opponent who will be "pro" will argue in favor of the death penalty. Whoever my opponent will be
column2: I would like to wish them good luck and hope for an interesting and fun debate. Here is my reasoning on why the death penalty is a bad thing. One of the strongest reasons I think why the death penalty is a bad idea is the amount of innocent people that it has killed. The justice system is not perfect and many innocent people have been convicted by it. The problem with the death penalty is that there is no way to go back on sentences and fix mistakes when new information about a case is found. There have been a number of people in the US who have been sentenced to death who later have been found out to be innocent. If these people were just sent to prison
column3: these mistakes could have been reversed and fixed. Secondly
column4: I find the argument that the death penalty will deter crime to be a bad one. I feel that this is very logical. If someone is that messed up in the head to even consider killing someone or doing something equally as bad and inhumane
column5: do you really think that the prospect of death is going to deter them from doing it? Additionally
column6: one thing that I've noticed many people who are in favour of the death penalty don't realize is that the death penalty is in fact very expensive. According to the Death Penalty Information Centre
column7: in the US

column9: 000 in imprisonment
column11: 000 in trial)
column12: While the average costs for a death penalty case are $3 million ($1. 3 million in imprisonment
column13: $1. 7 million in trial). For these reasons and more

column1: 490	Although some people argue that the death penalty is cruel and unusual
column2: the fact remains that it does cross the minds of most criminals before they commit a murder. According to Michael Kronenwetter
column3: interviews with the Los Angeles Police Department in the early 1970s revealed that half of the 99 criminals surveyed attributed their decision not to carry lethal weapons to the fear of the death penalty. This demonstrates that the threat of the death penalty may be cruel and unusual
column4: but it can also be quite effective in deterring crime.

498	The death penalty is ineffective, inefficient, and morally wrong. It should be discarded. Sources: [1] https://www.wcl.american.edu... [2] http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org... [3] http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org... [4] http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org... [5] https://www.prisonactivist.org.... Retribution is not a valid goal for punishment. Life imprisonment is a more cost-effective and morally acceptable form of punishment than the death penalty. Incapacitation and rehabilitation cannot be the sole goals of punishment, but life imprisonment can achieve both. Public education cannot be the sole goal of punishment, but life imprisonment can also achieve this end. Therefore, the death penalty is not the best way to accomplish any of these goals, and should be discarded. It is morally wrong, inefficient, and observably ineffective in accomplishing several key goals. Historical purposes of punishment include retribution, deterrence, rehabilitation, incapacitation, and public education. The death penalty provides retribution, but life imprisonment is less costly and an equally valid form of retribution. The death penalty does not deter, but life imprisonment does not deter either. Rehabilitation is a non-starter, but life imprisonment and rehabilitation can coexist. Incapacitation is an invalid goal by itself, but life imprisonment is still valid. Public education is a difficult goal to prove, but life imprisonment can also achieve this end. Overall, life imprisonment is the better form of punishment because it is less costly, more effective, and more moral. The death penalty is not morally permissible, inefficient, and observably ineffective in accomplishing several key goals. It should be discarded.
499	The death penalty is a barbaric punishment that has been repeatedly proven inefficient and ineffective. It fails to provide any tangible benefit to society and is a violation of the Eighth Amendment. Not only is it ineffective in deterring crime, it also leads to the execution of innocent people. Furthermore, it is unequally applied and often based on racial and socioeconomic biases. The cost of maintaining the death penalty is also excessive when compared to life imprisonment, which offers a much greater deterrent to crime without risking the execution of innocent people. Additionally, the possibility of rehabilitation is denied to death row inmates. The death penalty should be completely abolished and replaced with more humane forms of punishment. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_penalty#Efficacy_and_fairness.  ## Death Penalty: Con  The death penalty should be abolished. It is irreversible and capriciously applied, leading to the execution of innocent people. Additionally, it has been proven to be ineffective as a deterrent for crime, and is a violation of the 8th Amendment. It costs a lot more to maintain than life imprisonment, which offers a greater deterrent to crime without the risk of executing innocent people. Rehabilitation is also denied to death row inmates. The death penalty should be replaced with more humane forms of punishment. Source: https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2020/06/the-problem-with-the-death-penalty/593177/.

column2: the need for more experts and attorneys
column3: as well as two trials instead of one. These costs add up to a net expense to the state and the taxpayers
column4: making the death penalty an unsustainable burden. Therefore
column5: the death penalty should be abolished.

column1: 520	1. Death Penalty does not necessarily reduce crime
column2: as evidenced by the U.S. government's botched execution of an innocent man in Texas in 1982
column3: which sparked a riot and caused significant harm to the reputation of the justice system (Jenssen 2013). 2. Gun Control is an effective way to reduce crime
column4: as evidenced by the drastic reduction of crime in Australia following the implementation of strict gun control in 1996 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention 2017). 3. The death penalty is cost-inefficient
column5: as the expense of a trial and the appeals process can often exceed the cost of imprisonment for life (Tapper 2014).  4. Removing the death penalty does not necessarily result in increased crime rates
column6: as evidenced by the states that have abandoned the death penalty
column7: such as Missouri (Bellucci 2016). 5. The death penalty is not necessarily morally justified
column8: as some people may consider the death penalty to be a violation of the Eighth Amendment (Nelson 2017). 6. Executions are not necessarily a deterrent to crime
column9: as evidenced by studies which found that the death penalty is not a more effective deterrent than the alternative punishment of life imprisonment (Smith and Thas 2003). 7. Capital punishment is not necessarily more humane than life imprisonment
column10: as executions can go wrong and cause unnecessary suffering (Tong 2013). 8. The death penalty is not necessarily the best method of punishment
column11: as there are other punishments that can serve as effective alternatives (Lefcourt 2016). 9. The death penalty does not necessarily serve as retribution for the victims and their families
column12: as there is no guarantee that the family will ever find closure (Ansley 2017).

column1: 610	Every company and every individual in the world is a potential target for Google. Google CEO Eric Schmidt has stated that they aim to “have the strongest advertising network and all the world’s information”. This suggests that Google wishes to collect and use as much information as possible
column2: including from individuals. This also suggests that Google aims to make money from advertising
column3: by providing targeted advertising to their users. Therefore
column4: regardless of whether individuals are aware of it
column5: Google is collecting information on them
column6: as well as providing access to information from all over the world. This can include unreliable sources which are often displayed as the top results in Google searches. This means that even though individuals may not consider certain sources to be credible
column7: they are still accessible through Google and may be influential in forming an individual's opinion. It is important to be aware of this and make sure that individuals are taking into account the source's credibility before believing its content. By ensuring that individuals are critically evaluating the sources they access
column8: they can take steps to protect themselves from potentially being manipulated by unreliable information. Ultimately
column9: the choice of sources available through Google is not necessarily a virtuous one
column10: and it is up to the individual to make sure that they are not being influenced by unreliable sources.

column1: 611	“Every company and every individual in the world is a potential target for Google’s data collection. Google CEO Eric Schmidt stated that they need all of the information available
column2: including personal information
column3: in order to provide their advertising services. This could pose a problem for people who don’t want their personal information to be collected and used by a giant corporation such as Google. Furthermore
column4: they would also like to provide advertising services to content owners
column5: which could lead to users being exposed to biased or misleading information. Is the Google world a safe and virtuous one?”  This means that even though I would prefer to get my science news largely from trusted sources such as the New Scientist or Scientific American
column6: their articles are often not Google’s top results for scientific queries
column7: so I am often forced to click on unsavory sources to get my information. Additionally
column8: since Google prioritizes profits over accuracy
column9: unreliable sources are given leeway
column10: leading to a massive amount of misinformation being spread. Children
column11: who are especially vulnerable to misinformation
column12: are being exposed to this unreliable information and are likely to be confused and misled. This is a major issue that needs to be addressed
column13: as it can lead to life-altering decisions being made on misinformation.

column1: 612	Google is a dominant force in the way information is accessed today. With so much at stake
column2: it is important that we make sure the information we access is reliable and accurate. Google’s motto is to “Organize the world’s information”
column3: yet their algorithm prioritizes unreliable sources over reliable ones
column4: making it difficult to distinguish trustworthy information from untrustworthy. This can lead to misinformation being spread and accepted
column5: as well as more serious issues such as influencing public opinion or damaging individuals’ credibility. For instance
column6: spammy miracle cure reports falsely attributed to celebrities are easily found in the Google sphere
column7: and with children exposed to this type of misinformation
column8: their impressionable minds can be damaged. We must make sure that Google is held accountable for the reliable information it provides and the implications this has on our society. We need to ensure that the algorithm can be used to filter out unreliable sources and not prioritize them. We should also push for more awareness to be raised on the issue
column9: so that people can make an informed decision on the information they consume. By making sure reliable sources are more visible in the Google sphere
column10: and by teaching people to critically analyse information
column11: we can ensure that misinformation is reduced and truthful information is prioritized.

column1: 613	“Every company and every individual in the world is a Google target. Google CEO Eric Schmidt recently stated that “we are in the search business
column2: so we need all of the information…We’re also in the advertising business
column3: and we’d like to provide advertising services to people who have their own proprietary content. So depending on where we are in that spectrum
column4: we either do an advertising deal or a content deal or a hybrid deal. But ultimately our goal at Google is to have the strongest advertising network and all the world’s information
column5: that’s part of our mission.” This means that even though I personally don't always trust the Daily Mail newspaper as the most credible source of information on anything
column6: I'm still likely to click on its links because they are usually the top Google results for whatever I search for. Similarly
column7: restricted academic Journals accessible only via Student portals/Moodles/JSTOR are harder for me to use as references because they are not globally/universally accessible. Google wants all of "the world's information" (including individuals’ personal information)
column8: it wants to sell advertising to all of the world and it wants to distribute its advertising throughout all of the world. Is the Google world circle a virtuous one?

column1: 614	Google CEO Eric Schmidt has said that the company's mission is to "have the strongest advertising network and all the world's information". This indicates that Google aims to collect and distribute information from all over the world
column2: including individuals' personal information
column3: in order to generate advertising revenue. Therefore
column4: even though a user might not find a particular newspaper to be the most credible source of information on a given topic
column5: they might be more likely to click on its links due to its high Google ranking. Additionally
column6: restricted academic journals which are accessible only via student portals
column7: Moodles
column8: or JSTOR are harder for the average user to access
column9: even though many (e.g. the Lancet) are far better sources of information than top Google results. This implies that Google's worldview may not always be a virtuous one. After all
column10: just because something is accessible on the internet does not necessarily make it accurate or reliable. Ultimately
column11: it is up to individuals to use their own judgement and source critically when doing research
column12: rather than simply accepting what Google presents them with. This is especially important for children
column13: who are more likely to trust information they find online without questioning it. Therefore
column14: it is essential for parents and guardians to teach children to use the internet critically and safely.

column1: 616	You are right that Bing does not have as many services as Google does. However
column2: Bing's services are still worthwhile. For instance
column3: Bing Docs isn't as powerful as Google Docs
column4: but it still has some useful features
column5: such as the ability to auto-correct spelling and grammar mistakes. Furthermore
column6: Bing's video and image search are superior to Google's due to features such as Photo Synth
column7: which can generate 3D images of a scene. Additionally
column8: Bing Maps has features such as Bird's Eye and the possibility to post your own picture in 3D
column9: which are superior to Google Maps. Additionally
column10: route suggestions on Bing Maps are more accurate in commercial areas
column11: since they take into account traffic patterns and other variables. Finally
column12: Bing's AI capabilities such as its "virtual assistant" and its "spellchecker" are more powerful and accurate than Google's offerings. Thus
column13: Bing's services are definitely worthwhile. Additionally
column14: the user testimonials published on Microsoft's blog as well as the video that accompanies it demonstrate that people find Bing's services to be helpful and efficient. Furthermore
column15: several users have even reported that they have switched from Google to Bing and have experienced an overall improvement in their productivity. All in all
column16: Bing's services are certainly worthwhile and can even be considered superior to Google's in certain regards.

column1: 620	Google has been at it for longer-and it shows. Experience plays a significant role in Google's and Microsoft's ability to compete in the search space. Google has spent more than a decade tweaking its search to ensure that it adequately appeals to user desire. Microsoft
column2: on the other hand
column3: has only really been competing earnestly in the search space for a couple years. It was only a few years ago when Microsoft finally woke up and realized that if it doesn't improve its standing in the search market
column4: it could lose its profitability and be kept out of the Web. That lack of experience is showing with Bing. Although the search engine has come a long way in the last year that it has been available
column5: Google
column6: the veteran
column7: is still far ahead. 7. It's Caffeinated Google announced recently that it has moved to a new indexing service
column8: called Caffeine. According to the company
column9: Caffeine offers "50 percent fresher results for Web searches" than its last index. That's extremely important. Rather than waiting days
column10: weeks and sometimes months for content to get added to Google's index
column11: it could now take minutes or hours. Not only will that help content providers
column12: it will also improve the experience of searchers who want to find information on some of the news they heard about that day. Bing is still far behind when it comes to indexing speeds. 8. The focus is all wrong The focus of Google and Bing couldn't be any different. Google attempts to find the best solutions to improve its search for users. It realizes that if users are happy
column13: its profits will soar. And its recent financial statements have reflected that success. Microsoft's Bing search engine is much different. For one
column14: Microsoft is focusing too much of its time and energy on what Google is doing. It also believes that the more content available in search results
column15: the more people will like it. Microsoft must eventually realize that search is about users first and foremost if it wants to compete in that market. 9. Mobile integration Google's willingness to bring search to several mobile devices has significantly helped the company stay atop the search market. Google Search is the default service on the company's mobile operating system
column16: Android OS. Even better
column17: it's also the default search engine on the iPhone. In fact
column18: only recently did Apple announce that Bing would also be offered as an option in the company's mobile operating system. Google's mobile integration has been extremely important to the company. Not only does it potentially expose more users to its service
column19: it also keeps current users from trying out Bing. Until Microsoft makes a significant play for search in the mobile market
column20: it will be hard-pressed to catch up to Google. 10. Information takes center stage As mentioned
column21: Bing spends too much time with extras. But Google Search is different. Google's search page reveals everything users need to know about the company's strategy: Simplicity and information must trump all. It works. Although Google is starting to add more features to its search
column22: it's still much simpler than any other service on the Web. Information matters most to Google
column23: and its results-page design reflects that. Google is simply better at search than Bing right now. That doesn't mean Bing isn't worth trying out
column24: but it does mean that from an experience perspective
column25: it has a long way to go to match Google.

column1: 670	Thank you for the great debate topic. Pro's definition of veganism is that of the ethical vegan
column2: which is the orthodox side of veganism. Other types of veganism exist such as dietary veganism
column3: where the reasons for becoming a vegan are more for personal health benefits rather than for the salvation of animals. According to wikipedia
column4: dietary vegans "emphasize the health benefits of plant-based diets and may not necessarily oppose the use of animal products for clothing
column5: home furnishings
column6: or other non-food items".  http://en.wikipedia.org...  I would class the dietary vegans in somewhat of a conservative or reformed type of veganism. Some ethical (orthodox) vegans do not like dietary vegans to be called real vegans because they aren't fully converted to the full vegan lifestyle. http://www.theveganwoman.com...  You'll see me draw several parallels between veganism and religion in my arguments as I will show that vegansim is very much a type of religion. It's not a religion that touches the subject of God
column7: but its a religion where the orthodox adherents must not waver in their vegan beliefs or actions unless they are to be ridiculed and excommunicated from the community of orthodox vegans. I hold that every person should have the freedom to do what they choose
column8: live the life they want to live
column9: and live with the positive or negative consequences of their decisions. Pro's argument is that "people should become vegan because it is a better lifestyle
column10: and that way we don't harm or kill animals." In his argument
column11: con did not specify which lifestyle he is comparing to veganism. I can only assume he meant that becoming a vegan is the best lifestyle over all other lifestyles until he states otherwise. Pro must also define what he means by "people." Should all people become vegan? Should a few
column12: some
column13: half
column14: or most people become vegan? Should I become vegan? Should Pro himself become a vegan if he is not already? If pro doesn't redefine
column15: I will take "people" to mean all people on Earth. The foregoing are key pieces to the debate
column16: so I hope that Pro will define his argument much better in the next post.
