column1: 675	Con
column2: I apologize for not responding to your first argument and thank you for providing me with a more appropriate definition of what veganism is. I would also like to note that you did not specify which type of veganism you were referring to either. I can only assume you were referring to the stricter forms of veganism
column3: such as raw veganism or fruitarianism
column4: which is why I focused my argument on those types of veganism. This goes to show that different types of veganism require different lifestyles and eating habits to adhere to
column5: and that veganism is not a one-size-fits-all approach to health. I would like to point out that while the health benefits of veganism are many
column6: veganism is not a guaranteed healthier lifestyle. Just as people can eat unhealthily as vegetarians or vegans
column7: so too can they eat unhealthily as raw vegans or fruitarian. It is impossible to guarantee that a person will be healthier for having adopted a vegan lifestyle. Furthermore
column8: I would also like to point out that you have yet to provide a counter-argument to my statement that veganism is the most ethical way to live. All you have done so far is state the opposing viewpoint and attempt to refute it. You have yet to offer an argument in support of the idea that a vegan lifestyle is not ethical.  The link you provided does not contradict my argument. In fact
column9: it supports it. The article mentions that silkworms are now mostly bred in homes and farms
column10: which means that the wild populations of silkworms are almost completely gone. This implies that human activity is leading to the endangerment and possibly extinction of species. This also illustrates the point that veganism is the most ethical lifestyle choice because veganism seeks to minimize our impact on the environment and reduce animal suffering. Furthermore
column11: the article mentions that veganism is beneficial for the environment because it reduces methane emissions and soil erosion
column12: which further supports my argument that veganism is the most ethical lifestyle choice.   I will conclude by noting that veganism is an ever-evolving lifestyle that promotes compassion
column13: environmentalism
column14: and health. It is important to remember that veganism is a personal decision and that there is no one way to practice veganism. Every vegan should find the lifestyle that works best for them
column15: be it a raw vegan
column16: fruitarian
column17: or even omnivore.

column9:
but fails to acknowledge that veganism is not a requirement for a healthy lifestyle. This is an important point as Con has already established that veganism is not the healthiest diet. Pro should address this point.   Fourth, Pro claims that veganism is better for the environment, but again offers no evidence to back this up. Con has already presented evidence to the contrary.   Fifth, Pro argues that veganism is delicious, but fails to acknowledge that many people find vegan food to be bland and unappealing. Con has already presented evidence that vegan food can be just as enjoyable as food with animal products.   Overall, Pro has made some improvements to her argument, but there are still some points that need to be addressed in order for Pro's argument to be successful.
678	Con, I apologize for not specifying which lifestyle I was referring to. I can only assume you meant that being a vegan is the best lifestyle compared to other lifestyles. Since you have failed to make an argument for why veganism is the best lifestyle, I'll make one for why it isn't. Eating a vegan diet can be more expensive and difficult to obtain all the necessary vitamins and minerals. Eating a vegan diet also excludes many cultural and traditional foods that include animal products. Additionally, some people may have ethical concerns with not eating animal products. Finally, veganism may not be as healthy as an omnivorous diet since it is lacking in essential nutrients. I hope this clarifies my stance and lets me make a solid argument for why veganism may not be the best lifestyle. Thank you. Sorry for the delay. Hope this helps explain my stance. 679	Con, you mentioned that I did not specify which lifestyle I was comparing veganism to. The lifestyle I was comparing veganism to was the healthiest and safest lifestyle one can have. By people, I meant all people in general. Not all people on Earth, because as you stated, that would be boring. And I doubt everyone would be vegan anyway. There is always a rebel, don't you agree? People as in unhealthy people, people who need a healthier life. People who are against animal cruelty. If you don't want to become vegan, its your choice. After all, God did give us freewill.   I am sorry for not specifying which type of lifestyle I was comparing veganism to. It was a oversight on my part. I am not comparing veganism to any other type of lifestyle. I was trying to say, it is healthier and safer. By people, I meant people. Not all people on Earth, because as you stated, that would be boring. And I doubt everyone would be vegan anyway. There is always a rebel, don't you agree? People as in unhealthy people, people who need a healthier life. People who are against animal cruelty. If you don't want to become vegan, its your choice. After all, God did give us freewill.   I hope that this clears up any confusion and I look forward to your response.  Take care, <name> (if it is a she, refer to her as she)  (if it is a he, refer to him as he)
680	Resolved: Well planned vegan diets are healthier than their meat-based counterparts.  Terms: Well planned diet: A diet which can be designed by a layperson with a reasonable amount of research Vegan (or plant-based) diet: A diet that excludes animal body parts, animal milk and eggs Healthier: Greater longevity and freedom from disease Meat-based (or animal-based) diet: A diet which regularly consists of animal products (body parts, animal milk and eggs) In this debate, I will argue that plant-based diets are healthier than meat-based diets. I will highlight the virtues of vegan diets and the vices of meat-based diets. My opponent will do the opposite; pointing out the flaws of a vegan diet and arguing in favor of a meat based one. This debate will be based on dietetic evidence obtained from modern, reputable scientific studies.   Discussing what evolution designed" us for or what our physiology "proves" we should eat can be interesting. However
column10: I would encourage my opponent to base his or her arguments on modern dietetic science as I think this is more relevant to the resolution. During the debate I will point out the role animal-based foods play in cardiovascular disease
column11: cancer
column12: obesity and diabetes. I will respond to criticisms of well planned vegan diets as my opponent provides them.  In this round
column13: I will begin with cardiovascular disease:  World-wide
column14: cardiovascular diseases such as ischemic heart disease and cerebrovascular disease end more lives prematurely than anything else[1][2]. In North America
column15: CVD accounts for 40% of all deaths[3]. The American Heart Association estimates that "79
column17: 000 American adults (one in three) have one or more types of cardiovascular disease"[4].   Dietary cholesterol is only found in animal foods[5] and is not necessary for humans to consume as it is naturally produced by the liver[6][7]. Scientist estimate that for every 1% increase in cholesterol levels
column18: the risk of heart disease raises by 2-3%[3].  Saturated fats
column19: transfatty acids and dietary cholesterol are the most significant causes of hypercholesterolemia (elevated cholesterol levels)[3]. Of all dietary groups
column20: vegans have the lowest levels of these substances in their blood[3]. Furthermore
column21: the substances that mitigate hypercholesterolemia are soluble fiber
column22: plant protein (especially soy protein)
column23: polyunsaturated fats and phytochemicals[3]. These substances are only found in plant foods and are
column24: as a consequence
column25: more abundant in vegans[3]. In summary
column26: vegans have the lowest risk of developing cardiovascular disease; the leading cause of deaths.

column1: 681	Vegan diets are becoming increasingly popular amongst health conscious individuals and are associated with numerous health benefits. However
column2: a vegan diet may be healthier in the long-term
column3: it could be detrimental to your health in the short-term if not planned correctly. It is important to make sure that your vegan diet is well planned in order to meet your nutritional needs and get the most out of it. A well planned vegan diet can include a variety of fruits and vegetables
column4: legumes
column5: nuts and whole grains. It also should include a variety of plant-based protein sources such as tofu
column6: tempeh
column7: beans
column8: lentils
column9: and nuts. Furthermore
column10: a well planned vegan diet should also contain a variety of vitamins and minerals to ensure you get enough of everything you need. On the other hand
column11: a poorly planned vegan diet can lack essential nutrients
column12: leading to deficiencies
column13: which can have a negative effect on your health. Additionally
column14: a vegan diet may be more expensive than a non-vegan diet due to the higher cost of plant-based foods. It is important to take all of these factors into consideration when discussing the health implications of a vegan diet. While well planned vegan diets can be very healthy and provide numerous benefits
column15: they should be balanced with consideration of cost
column16: accessibility
column17: and nutrition in order to provide the greatest health benefit.  To conclude
column18: a vegan diet may be healthier in the long-term but should be planned properly in order to meet the individual's nutritional needs and get the most out of it. Additionally
column19: a vegan diet may be more expensive than a non-vegan diet due to the higher cost of plant-based foods.

column1: 690	Definitions: Veganism is the practice of abstaining from the use of animal products
column2: particularly in diet
column3: as well as following an associated philosophy that rejects the commodity status of sentient animals http://en.wikipedia.org... product - something produced; especially : commodity 1 (2) : something (as a service) that is marketed or sold as a commodity http://www.merriam-webster.com... The Cummunist Manifesto “Let the guzzling classes tremble at a Cummunist revolution. The harlotarians have nothing to lose but their chains. They have a world to win.” –Karl “Big Gulp” Marx The vegan ethos is motivated by the recognition that neither man nor beast may be made an object to be sucked dry by the ruling classes. Vegans see ethical worth in all sentient beings and so refuse to partake in the reification of animals. Meat and leather represent the coercive transformation of a sentient being into an object to be sold and consumed. Swallowing semen is consensual act- the sperm is willingly expelled from the body with joy and vigor. Barring fringe cases of prostitution
column4: the vegan is not making the sperm donor an object to be bought and sold; the vegan is not reducing the sentient spewer to a piece of meat. Simply put
column5: spunk ain’t a commodity. Oral sex and the eager lapping that follows is not only wholly within the ethical bounds of veganism
column6: it solves the inequalities vegans object to. In his semenal work
column7: Marx noted: “In proportion as the exploitation of one individual by another is put an end to
column8: the exploitation of one nation by another will also be put an end to. In proportion as the antagonism between classes within the nation vanishes
column9: the hostility of one nation to another will come to an end.” Swallowing is an act which bridges the divide between classes. It removes antagonism as the donor appreciates the moral fortitude of the vegan for finishing the job through to the end.

column1: 700	I've been kinda sorta vegan for about a year
column2: and frankly
column3: I hate it. I'd love to be convinced that I can throw this aside and go back to eating delicious things like cheese. Though full disclosure I haven't been able to force myself into a fully plant-based diet and have had a weekly cheat day. The spirit is willing but the flesh is weak and all that.  Things I consider facts:  * Animal suffering is bad. * The environment damage and global warming is bad. * Individuals must be willing to make sacrifices for ethical reasons even if their contribution is small. * Health impact is already not a factor for me (I don't think being vegan is clearly healthier).  I won't get mad if you try to argue those but you're not likely to shift me on those basic principles.   &#x200B;  These facts I could be wrong about or missing some key aspect of:  * Buying animal products directly supports a system that causes animal suffering. * Buying animal products is harmful for the environment (relative to eating plants) because of emissions

column1: 825	Pro accepts that Donald is calling for "a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States". Then Pro attempts to dispute this statement as being racist using two different tactics. #1 Pro implies that this policy is somehow not racist because it would be limited in duration. Racism is racism regardless of the duration. Limited discrimination does not make it not-discrimination. #2 Pro states that this policy is not racist because it is aimed only at immigrants from countries with terrorism propagated by Islam To this I have two responses: Donald's statement says "total and complete shutdown of Muslims"
column2: and does not mention limitations to any particular countries. Pro's argument is not backed by the text in Donald's statement. Furthermore
column3: changing from a racist policy to a non-racist policy later does not make his original policy non-racist
column4: nor does it make Donald not-racist. Finally
column5: Pro has not address my argument at all
column6: and it still stands. - Donald Trump campaigned on a policy to prevent specifically Muslims from entering the United States
column7: which is discriminatory against Muslims. - Donald Trump campaigned to discriminate against Muslims. - Discrimination against Muslims is internationally recognized as a form of racism -> Donald Trump campaigned using racism -> Donald Trump is racist.
